Series III: Reports

scopecontent.p: Boxes 112-134

The BASR Reports were generally delivered to the research sponsor in mimeographed form. In some cases, as noted, the reports were later published as articles or books. Asterisks indicate titles which are not included in the microfiche collection.

did.unittitle: Paul F. Lazarsfeld and Edward A. Suchman Initial Report on an Exploratory Study of Coverage by Radio Stations., 1941
did.physdesc: ( 6 pp. plus charts Questionnaire, notes on staffing coverage.)

scopecontent.p: [Examples of data available about kind of audiences government agencies may reach by sponsoring radio programs, such as availability of people, general listening habits, station and program preference.]

did.unittitle: Paul F. Lazarsfeld, M. Bayne and Edward A. Suchman Station Coverage Report. 1941

scopecontent.p: [Discusses availability of people as listeners, information on station coverage and program structure. Questionnaire to stations included: What America Listened to on Wednesday, Dec. 4.]

did.unittitle: Ernest Dichter Study of Psychological Programs., 1939.

scopecontent.p: [From interviews, which are given verbatim, two major themes were found in the various self-improvement programs. They offered explanations of psychological facts and they appealed to the listener to overcome difficulties or to accept unchangeable situations. The resultant good or bad effects upon the listener are discussed.]

did.unittitle: Plugging Study. T. W. Adomo and Douglas MacDougald, 1939

scopecontent.p: [ A discussion of the total business setting which decides whether or not a song is to become a hit- Tin Pan Alley. A sketch of the life story of a popular song with emphasis on plugging of songs and how it is carried out. See also "The Popular Music Industry" by MacDougald, pp. 65-109 in Radio Research 1941.]

did.unittitle: Jack N. Peterman Your Hit Parade-Preliminary and Supplementary Reports, 1940

scopecontent.p: [Discussion and report on how to better the Hit Parade rating system which measures relative popularity of songs.]

did.unittitle: Trienah Meyers Lucky Strike Hit Parade, 1942

scopecontent.p: [A comparison of Hit Parade ratings, using different methods. Description of moves of five places or more in one week by Hit Parade songs. How eight songs moved. Hit Parade weaknesses.]

did.physdesc: (5 folders containing Typed report on Princeton project and Columbia report on BASR from 1968-69, 1 separate pamphlet)

did.unittitle: Lazarsfeld, Berelson, & Gaudet 1940 Voting Study: How the Voter Makes Up His Mind in a Presidential Campaign, 1940
did.physdesc: (35 folders containing Folder 1 empty, Folder 34 missing, two folder 35's, Code for Erie, Peoples Choice- Sandusky)

scopecontent.p: [ (The People's Choice: Erie County Study: Sandusky Study) (note, there was no report submitted)]

did.unittitle: Content of Magazine Stories and the Socio-Economic Aspirations of Their Readers. Jack N. Peterman, 1949

scopecontent.p: [A content analysis of the socioeconomic aspirations expressed by the characters, background, plot and general philosophy of magazine stories and presumably aroused in the readers.]

did.unittitle: Paul F. Lazarsfeld and Madorie Fleiss Progress Report on the Development of a Spending Test, 1940
did.physdesc: (B-0092-1 40 pp., B-0092-2 13 pp.; 4folders Notes, Questionnaire, questions & typescript, test)

scopecontent.p: [Desc: A scale was set up based on questions which reflected people's spending habits. B-0092-2 consists of interviewers' comments on the spending test survey.]

did.unittitle: Marjorie Fleiss Should Bloomingdale's Maintain Its Restaurant? 1940
did.physdesc: (13 pp.; 3 folders containing Reports, Bloomingdale Restaurant study, card coder)

scopecontent.p: [Desc: Would customers feel Bloomingdale's service to them was curtailed, would prestige of store be lowered, do financial returns of restaurant justify its upkeep? Stratified by income of 421 respondents.]

did.unittitle: Lazarsfeld & Gaudet Shortwave Radio Listening in Erie County, 1940 (?)
did.physdesc: (4 folders containing Memos, Repsondent lists, questionnaire, draft reports)

scopecontent.p: [Report not available]

did.unittitle: T.W. Adorno Analytical Study of the NBC Music Appreciation Hour, 1940 (?)
Paul F. Lazarsfeld American Station Sampler and How to Use It., 1940
did.physdesc: (6 pp.; 2 folders containing folder content sent to Vienna, codebooks)

scopecontent.p: [A chart listing 11 separate sets of radio stations-all stations in U.S. and territories included. Discussion of station sampling procedure.]

did.unittitle: R. Arnheim, E. Suchman and M. Bayne Small Stations Survey: Preliminary Memorandum, 1941

scopecontent.p: [Preliminary analysis: number of hours and what language, types of programs, news items-domestic or foreign, drama-local or foreign, types of national appeals, etc.]

did.unittitle: Rudolf Arnheim, Edward Suclunan and M. Bayne Foreign Language Broadcasts Over Local American Stations, 1941

scopecontent.p: [This paper presents available evidence on the problems of such broadcasting. A questionnaire was filled out by 66 specially appointed listeners covering 800 hours of foreign language broadcasts across the country. They also could present summaries of their observations. Published. See pp. 3-64 in Radio Research 1941.]

did.unittitle: Suchman & Friedrich Italian Language Program Audiences, 1941

scopecontent.p: [1 is missing, 2&3 are empty (copies in Vienna), Codebook, Questionnaire instructions. Report not submitted]

did.unittitle: Herta Herzog Feelings Among Four Minority Groups in New York City-Mayoralty Election as a Test Situation., 1941
did.physdesc: (25 pp.; 1 folder containing empty folder (copy in Vienna))

scopecontent.p: [A discussion of how the decision for whom to vote in the 1941 mayoralty election will be determined by racial and national fears and prejudices. Based on 57 detailed interviews among Jewish, Italian, Irish and German people.]

did.unittitle: Paul F. Lazarsfeld The Daytime Serial as a Social, Commercial and Research Problem, 1942
did.physdesc: (51 pp.; 11 folders containing Questionnaires, Questions & memos, draft reports, folders 5-7 are empty (#5 in Vienna), Analysis , Content Analysis, Analysis- Soap Opera in Italian)

scopecontent.p: [This sets forth the social and commercial problems created by daytime radio serials, reviews what is known, and suggests areas which need further exploration. The research methods which might be used are also discussed.]

did.unittitle: Herta Herzog Daytime Serials: Their Audience and Their Effect on Buying, 1942

scopecontent.p: [Based on survey of 5000 women, this gives a broad general picture of women's daytime listening habits and the effect of listening upon actual use of product advertised.]

did.unittitle: Herta Herzog News and Views on John B. Hughes, 1942

scopecontent.p: [Hughes was a commentator who took over Raymond Graham Swing's time spot on the radio. This is a discussion of his selection and treatment of topics, comprehensibility, voice, opinion shaping, and comparison with other commentators. How to sell the product advertised on his program is also discussed.]

did.unittitle: Herta Herzog Study on Stomach Distress, 1942
did.physdesc: (50 pp.; 4 folders containing Codebook and studies)

scopecontent.p: [310 interviewed, questionnaire included. Attitudes toward stomach troubles, remedies.]

did.unittitle: Herta Herzog Preliminary Test of Six Kolynos Commercials, 1942

scopecontent.p: [75 respondents were asked to compare commercials and were then interviews about them and about their own dentifrice use. Scripts and questionnaire included.]

did.unittitle: Herta Herzog Test of Kolynos Tooth Powder Commercials, 1942

scopecontent.p: [100 women heard four sets of Kolynos Tooth Powder commercials and were then interviewed about them and about their own dentifrice use. Scripts and questionnaire included. (missing file)]

did.unittitle: Herta Herzog Test on Bisodol Commercials, 1942

scopecontent.p: [76 people interviewed, questionnaire included. Problems posed were straight talk versus dramatized technique, personal versus straight descriptive approach commercial, as well as what properties of Bisodol should be stressed, sketchy versus detailed. (missing file)]

did.unittitle: Genevieve Knupfer The Buying of Vitamin Preparations, 1942

scopecontent.p: [Topics covered are who buys vitamins, how much do they spend, brands bought. Questionnaires included. Problems with the data supplied by Industrial Surveys Co. are discussed. (missing file)]

did.unittitle: Paul F. Lazarsfeld Should She Have Music?, 1942

scopecontent.p: [Assembles available information on whether and what kind of daytime musical program would reach middle-aged, middle-class women. Main source of data: survey of 5000 women in 1941 by Office of Radio Research.]

did.unittitle: Paul F. Lazarsfeld Reports to Curtis Publishing Company, 1941
did.physdesc: ( 77 pp.; 2 folders containing 1 empty folder (copy in Vienna), Research suggestions)

scopecontent.p: [This contains several reports dealing with the characteristics of Saturday Evening Post readers.]

did.unittitle: Manuel Manfield and Jeannette Green Sending and Receiving Greeting Cards, 1941
did.physdesc: ( 52 pp.; 1 empty folder containing copy in Vienna )

scopecontent.p: [193 persons interviewed by questionnaire and conversational interviews. Report discusses type of people interviewed, what greeting cards mean to people, resistance to them, cards as merchandise, the dealer. Questionnaires included.]

did.unittitle: M. Bayne Exploratory Study on the Psychology Refrigerator Purchasers, 1941
did.physdesc: (30 pp.; 2 folders containing empty folder (copy in Vienna), Questions)

scopecontent.p: [Based on 60 detailed interviews, a tentative analysis tries to answer such questions as: Do people have more subtle desires to which we could link the use of a refrigerator? Could we mobilize psychological forces which usually are not thought of in refrigerator ads?]

did.unittitle: Durant & Lazarsfeld Morale Survey, 1941

scopecontent.p: [No report submitted]

did.unittitle: Magazines vs. Radio Serials, 1941

scopecontent.p: [No report submitted]

did.unittitle: Leo Lowenthal Biographies in Popular Magazines. Published. See pp. 507-548 in Radio Research 1942-1943., 1942-1943
Paul F. Lazarsfeld General Statistical Analysis of Joint Newspaper-Radio Ownership, 1941
did.physdesc: (35 pp.; 21 folders containing and 2 loose leaf code binders )

scopecontent.p: [A statistical picture of distribution of newspapers and radio stations, and some of their main characteristics in the whole country.]

did.unittitle: Joint Ownership of Radio Stations and Newspapers in 1-1 Communities: A Statistical Analysis. Paul F. Lazarsfeld, 1941

scopecontent.p: [An analysis of 93 1-1 communities for which newspaper ownership of more than 50% is claimed. (1-1 community: radio stations and newspaper associated.) Power, frequency, population, newspaper circulation, network affiliation are variables taken into account.]

did.unittitle: Radio and Newspaper Affiliations. Paul Neurath, 1955

scopecontent.p: [Discusses in what communities newspapers disappear and the role in this disappearance played by radio and newspaper-radio affiliations.]

did.unittitle: A Comparison of News Programs, Educational Programs and Editorial Policy of Associated and Non-Associated Media. Herta Herzog, 1941

scopecontent.p: [50 radio stations were selected which were associated with a newspaper. 50 stations and 50 newspapers were selected which were not associated or owned one by the other. Then the 50 associated and non-associated stations were compared. Same was done for the 2 groups of newspapers.]

did.unittitle: Jeannette Green The American Community Leader Looks at the Drugstore, 1943
did.physdesc: (66 pp.; 3 folders containing Questionnaire, Talbes, Empty file (copy in Vienna) )

scopecontent.p: [Report based on 264 interviews in 13 cities, concerns attitude toward drugstores and pharmacists.]

did.unittitle: L. Kay Some Observations on Life Readers, 1943
did.physdesc: (16 pp.; 19 folders containing (plus 2 loose leaf binders) )

scopecontent.p: [intensive interviews were conducted toward a better understanding of the function of Life magazine as a medium of communication and as a social and political magazine.]

did.unittitle: Some Attitudes Toward Life Magazine-Final Report. Herta Herzog and L. Kay, 1943

scopecontent.p: [Perceptions of Life's editorial policy, Life compared with other magazines, why some don't read it, how thoroughly it is read as a news magazine, as a non-news magazine, as a picture magazine. Based on 200 interviews. Questionnaire included.]

did.unittitle: The Magazine Ogre. Herta Herzog, 1943

scopecontent.p: [General reading habits of Life, Saturday Evening Post, Collier's and Liberty readers; relation of multiplicity of magazine reading to intensity of reading.]

did.unittitle: Babette Kass Overlapping Magazine Reading: A New Method of Determining the Cultural Levels of Magazines. Published. See pp., 130-151 in Communications Research, 1948-1949., 1948-1949

scopecontent.p: [May not exist.]

did.unittitle: Gerhart Wiebe A Study of Three Radio Broadcasts Intended to Refute Rumors., 1942
did.physdesc: (35 pp.; 1 folder containing empty folder (copy in Vienna) )

scopecontent.p: [Excerpts from three broadcasts were studied to find their relative merit in terms of audience appeal and their effectiveness in "scotching" rumors. Program Analyzer and supplementary questionnaire were used. Questionnaire included.]

did.unittitle: Ernest Dichter Health Program Study., 1942
did.physdesc: (43 pp.; 1 folder containing empty folder (copy in Vienna))

scopecontent.p: [To establish the appeal of radio health programs, 14 people were interviewed and these interviews are given verbatim. A combination of factors was found to explain their continued interest.]

did.unittitle: Goodwin Watson Title:A Socio-Psychological Study of Wine Drinking-Summary. 1944
did.physdesc: (48 pp. 9 Folders. 1-4 folders containing are empty (Wine study copies in Vienna), Remainder contain Questionnaires, Code Books )

scopecontent.p: [Previous discussions of customs and wine drinking, social factors involved, special characteristics of wine drinkers, types of drinkers and the marketing of wine are summarized. Topics for further study are suggested. Original discussions are contained in interim reports under B-0160.]

did.unittitle: Kaufman "Why We Fight", 1940's (?)

scopecontent.p: [No Report submitted]

did.unittitle: Maurice L. Farber Report on Program Analyzer Test of Audition of "Ask Eleanor Nash.", 1942

scopecontent.p: [copy in Vienna. This report discusses the test group, their "like" and "dislike" reactions, reactions to Eleanor's voice and to the program as a whole. 18 women were in the sample.]

did.unittitle: Paul F. Lazarsfeld Magazine Reading Before and After Pearl Harbor, 1942
did.physdesc: (22 pp.; 3 folders containing Memorandums, Study Codes)

scopecontent.p: [Based on data obtained from Life, Inc., and Hearst Publications, Inc., this report investigates the changes in people's reading habits as a result of Pearl Harbor, especially with regard to the reading of nonfiction articles concerned with the war.]

did.unittitle: by the listeners. Weekly Reports on Shortwave Broadcasts to Germany and Italy, 1942
did.physdesc: (56 pp. empty folder, copy in Vienna)

scopecontent.p: [Discussion of unfavorable aspects of the programs and of technical problems.]

did.unittitle: Lowenthal and Lazarsfeld Philadelphia News and News Commentators Study, 1942
did.physdesc: (11 folders containing Tables, Codes,Notes, Commentaries, Analysis, Analysis of NY paper editorials, Memoranda, Monitors, Procedures)

scopecontent.p: [No report available]

did.unittitle: Peatman & Marcson "This is War" Program Tests, 1942
did.physdesc: (3 folders containing Report (copy in Vienna), Memos, Codebooks)

scopecontent.p: [No report available]

did.unittitle: Herta Herzog Pretesting a Short Story, 1942
did.physdesc: (15 pp.; 4 folders containing Report (empty, copy in Vienna), Story, Misc. memo, Pretesting- 8 questionnaires (confidential))

scopecontent.p: [Summary of findings of a reader test of 15 people to determine reactions to characters, plot, etc., of readers of a preliminary version of a novelette. Interviews and questionnaire included.]

did.unittitle: Jeannette Green Test of Golden Wedding Trademarks, 1943
did.physdesc: (18 pp.; 2 folders containing empty folder (in Vienna), Questionnaire)

scopecontent.p: [163 interviews were conducted with Protestant, Catholic and Jewish men and women to find out if the wedding ring on the Golden Wedding (whiskey) trademark was offensive to their religious and social feelings. Questionnaire included.]

did.unittitle: Genevieve Knupfer Poughkeepsie Social Stratification Study, 1943
did.physdesc: (6 folders containing Study, Correllations, Misc., Questionnaire, Codebook)

scopecontent.p: [No report available]

did.unittitle: Kay Birthday Cards Study, 1943
did.physdesc: (3 folders containing Questionnaire, Memo, Draft report)

scopecontent.p: [No report available]

did.unittitle: Marjorie Fiske Survey of Materials on the Psychology of Radio Listening, 1943

scopecontent.p: [The successful commercial use of radio rests upon an understanding of the interrelationship of the commercial and the informing and entertaining aspects of radio. This memorandum then, deals with "general psychology of radio, its power as a selling force, and some particular aspects of retailers' use of radio."]

did.unittitle: Robert K. Merton Time-Readership and the Influence Structure of Dover, N.J.: An Exploratory Study, 1943

scopecontent.p: [This report explores the meaning of influence in a community and its relation to the reading of Time magazine. In two field trips 86 interviews were secured from three groups of people: 1) influential people, 2) Time subscribers, 3) random people. Suggestions for further research are made and interview schedules are included.]

did.unittitle: Jeannette Green Study of the American Magazine, 1943
did.physdesc: (34 pp.; 21 folders containing Empty study (copy in Vienna), Questionnaires- 8 interviews, Codes- & codesheets, Interview instruction, Questionnaire, Tables, Misc., Procedures, Study comparisons, Criticisms, Preference trends, Commercial breakdowns, Gratifications, Psych. applied to publishing, Pages from magazines, Final study)

scopecontent.p: [315 people were interviewed, showing American Magazine steering a middle course between Cosmopolitan and Saturday Evening Post. Among people who read American Magazine, four main gratifications came to light.]

did.unittitle: Herta Herzog The Negro and the War-A Preliminary Test of an OWI Pamphlet, 1943
did.physdesc: (22 pp.; 19 folders containing Empty folder (file in Vienna), Questionnaires, Misc., Memos, Overall summary, Survey tables, Worksheets, Interview notes-instructions and correspondence, Scripts and script substitution, Commercials, , Question analysis, Stations responding, Statistical data, Comment analysis)

scopecontent.p: [Outlines responses of 70 Blacks interviewed to pamphlet itself and to idea conveyed by it that they should strongly support the war effort.]

did.unittitle: Marjorie Fiske Retailers' Use of Radio as Judged by the Consumer (Hartford, Conn.), 1943
did.physdesc: (19 pp.; 13 folders containing Questionnaires, Questions & codes, Codes, Interview instructions, Iowa study, Bibliography of department store study, Memos, Script materials, Study quotes, Analysis-tables)

scopecontent.p: [200 housewives were interviewed as to how local stores' advertising could be made most helpful with emphasis on use of radio. Questionnaire included.]

did.unittitle: Alberta Curtis Some Preliminary Observations on Kate Smith Listeners, 1944

scopecontent.p: [A discussion of how people felt about Kate Smith herself and in relation to her bond drive.]

did.unittitle: Robert K. Merton The Effectiveness of the Kate Smith Bond Drives, 1944

scopecontent.p: [On the basis of interviews conducted with persons who bought bonds from her and with persons who heard her but did not buy "some of the strong points of her campaign and types of resistance she encountered" are indicated.]

did.unittitle: Marjorie Fiske Bonds on the Air, 1944

scopecontent.p: ["A report of the public's choice as to who is best qualified to sell bonds on the radio, in which Kate Smith gets her share of attention." 978 people-a cross-section of the population of Greater New York-were interviewed.]

did.unittitle: Robert K. Merton and Marjorie Fiske Kate Smith, 1944

scopecontent.p: [Explores some of the general aspects of the radio marathon and then analyzes Kate Smith as a war bond salesman. Intensive interview guide (100 cases) and polling questionnaire (1000 cases) included.]

did.unittitle: Robert K. Merton and Patricia Kendall The Focused Interview, 1943
Marjorie Fiske and Arthur W. Komhauser Morale of Industrial Workers: A Summary and Point of View, 1943

scopecontent.p: [Part I-A survey of the literature of morale studies. Supplementary report: Music in Industry-a survey of the literature of research on music in industry. Extensive bibliographies included in both sections.]

did.unittitle: Israel Bias in Radio Newscasting, 1943

scopecontent.p: [No report available]

did.unittitle: Alberta Curtis How Should Tide Study its Readers? An Exploratory Study, 1943
did.physdesc: (48 pp.; 3 folders containing Interview and questionnaire. Questionnaire, study (empty, folder in Vienna report))

scopecontent.p: [Tide was an "entertaining" business magazine. Survey gained ideas on how different types of business executives varied in their opinions of Tide and its rival, Printer's Ink and on what problems needed further research; 56 interviewed, questionnaire included. See also B-0220.]

did.unittitle: Jeannette Green Test of Green River Trademark, 1944

scopecontent.p: [218 respondents were interviewed for the purpose of determining whether the picture of the black man on the Green River trademark connoted, (an inferior whiskey" or a "whiskey just for colored people." Interviewing was done in five cities of the deep South. Questionnaire included.]

did.unittitle: Jeannette Green Test of the Suggested New Green River Trademark, 1944

scopecontent.p: [60 people were questioned on whether enough of the old trademark remained in the new to make it easily identifiable. Questionnaire included.]

did.unittitle: Goodwin Watson A Critical Analysis of the Pictures in "There Are No Master Races" -Study # 1, 1945

scopecontent.p: [This was a comic book sponsored by the American Jewish Committee. About 350 persons were interviewed in groups of about 10-given preliminary questionnaire, shown comic, answered questionnaire a second time, then group discussion. Study # 1 discussed the reactions to the comic book as a whole, reactions to specific pictures, and whether or not comic books could be accepted as authoritative.]

did.unittitle: Goodwin Watson The Effects of "There Are No Master Races" Upon Knowledge and Attitude of Readers-Study #2, 1945

scopecontent.p: [After a single reading of the comic "There Are No Master Races" the average person's information score rose substantially. However, willingness to accept persons of other races was not much affected.]

did.unittitle: Bernard Berelson "The Story of Labor"-A Study of Readership, 1945
did.physdesc: (16 pp.; 5 folders containing Questions, Codes, Newspaper articles, Letters, Typed & printed studies)

scopecontent.p: [334 interviews completed to determine the extent to which one issue of the cartoon strip "The Story of Labor" was read by trade union members in their union publication, to identify the readers' characteristics, and to estimate the readers' comprehension of the strip. Questionnaire included.]

did.unittitle: Bernard Berelson "The Ghosts Go West"-A Report on Comprehension, 1945
did.physdesc: (24 pp.; 4 folders containing Questions, Report (empty folder, copy in Vienna), Codes, Letters & memos)

scopecontent.p: [This study tried to determine the comprehension, miscomprehension or non-comprehension by 300 respondents of a cartoon. Questionnaire included.]

did.unittitle: Bernard Berelson and Patricia Salter Writers' War Board Study, 1944
did.physdesc: (69 pp.; 12 folders containing Studies-empty folders (copies in Vienna), Codes, Logsheet, & abstracts, Correspondence, Memos, Reports, Reference materials, Pamphlets)

scopecontent.p: [1) Magazine Section-an analysis of American minority and foreign groups in popular magazine fiction. 2) Daytime serials- an analysis of previous study material as to treatment of minorities in daytime serials. 3) Summary of the literature on anti-minority prejudice. 4) Newsreels-an analysis of treatment of minority and foreign groups in newsreels. 5) Interviews on anti-minority prejudice in advertising copy. 6) Comic books and anti-minority prejudice.]

did.unittitle: Marjorie Fiske and Jeannette Green The Detailed Focused Interview as a Technique for the Testing of Institutional Advertising, 1944
did.physdesc: (16 pp.; 4 folders containing Interviews, Advertisement examples, Memos, Typed Study)

scopecontent.p: [The focused interview will shed light on why an ad is or is not successful, will indicate possible ways to improve the ad, will show how the ad affects readers' attitudes toward the company. The appendix discusses the three processes involved in this type of interview.]

did.unittitle: Marjorie Fiske Naples is a Battlefield-Preliminary Report on a Study of Audience Reaction with Lazarsfeld-Stanton Program Analyzer, 1944
did.physdesc: (50 pp.; 8 folders containing Questionnaires, Codes, Interview guide, Analysis, Memos)

scopecontent.p: [Discusses how audiences reacted to the film as recorded by the L-S analyzer, by group interviews, by "before and after" attitude tests, and by an "opinion of the film" questionnaire.]

did.unittitle: Bernard Berelson True Story Survey in Sandusky, Ohio-Final Report, 1944

scopecontent.p: [Summarizes what is known about opinion leadership and its relation to magazine reading based upon two surveys.]

did.unittitle: Bernard Berelson True Story Study of Opinion Leadership-Choice of Towns, 1945

scopecontent.p: [A detailed report on how the choice of towns for the study was narrowed to three.]

did.unittitle: Marjorie Fiske and Patricia Kendall Al Schacht as a Baseball Announcer-A Pre-Test, 1944

scopecontent.p: [24 people listened to a transcription of an Al Schacht broadcast, filled out questionnaires covering background information and their general impressions of him and then were interviewed in some detail as to their reasons for liking or disliking him.]

did.unittitle: Goodwin Watson Tide's Readers Say, 1944
did.physdesc: (52 pp.; 6 folders containing Empty folder (copy in Vienna), Interviews, Memos, Codes)

scopecontent.p: [This study tries to answer such questions as "What do its readers think of Tide's editorial policy? What articles do they like? What are the high spots in Tide? To what extent is it really read?" 395 advertising, manufacturing, and business executives were interviewed in detail. See also B-0210.]

did.unittitle: Patricia Kendall The Comparative Retention Value of Four Sloan's Liniment Commercials, 1944
did.physdesc: (25 pp.; 2 folders containing Report-empty folder (copy in Vienna), Codes)

scopecontent.p: [Questionnaires filled out by 384 people were used to determine which of four commercials was best remembered.]

did.unittitle: Marjorie Fiske Sampling of Public Attitudes Toward the Proposed Subscription Radio Plan, 1944
did.physdesc: (80 pp.; 2 folders containing Empty copy of study in Vienna, Questions & codes)

scopecontent.p: ["The object of this study was to gauge the degree of public receptivity toward the proposed subscription radio plan, as indicated both by the degree of interest in the plan itself and by the degree of satisfaction or dissatisfaction with current radio offerings." Questionnaire included. 1000 interviews in upper 3/4 of all economic levels around New York City were conducted.]

did.unittitle: Herta Herzog and Katherine Wolf "War Town" Series Report, 1945
did.physdesc: (5 pp.; 1 folder containing Notes study (copy in Vienna))

scopecontent.p: [14 programs of this radio series which portrayed a community service organization helping a person in distress were reviewed. This memorandum offers "observations which may be of some practical value in the planning of a similar program series in the future."]

did.unittitle: Psychological Analysis of One Newspaper, 1948
Synthetic Detergent Advertisement and One Radio Synthetic Detergent Commercial. Jeannette Green, 1948.

The respondents then heard an advertisement of the same product on the phonograph in an attempt to analyze what effect the use of each media has on the response to an advertisement. In half the interviews the order was reversed so that the respondents heard the advertisement before reading it.]

Questionnaire included.]

did.unittitle: Production-Maintenance Functions of the Urban Working Force. A. J. Jaffe, 1951

scopecontent.p: [This is an attempt to differentiate between workers performing production functions and workers performing maintenance functions and a consideration of the implications of such a division. Based on Canadian and U.S. census data.]

did.unittitle: The Stability of Cities: Some Considerations and Calculations. A. J. Jaffe, 1951

scopecontent.p: [A consideration of the stability of relationships among cities over a period of time, and of the stability of industrial relationships within single cities over a period of time.]

did.unittitle: A Survey of the Contents of Russian Censuses. Joseph Froomkin, 1951

scopecontent.p: [This paper is concerned with a descriptive survey of the contents of the Russian census describing in detail the census of 1926 and to a lesser extent those of 1897, 1917, 1920, and 1923. An explanation of definitions of terms is included.]

did.unittitle: A Comparative Study of Skill Designations in the U.S. and U.S.S.R. Joseph Froomkin and A. J. Jaffe, 1952

scopecontent.p: [An attempt to determine whether the difference in definition of skilled workers in the U. S. and U. S. S.R. is related to differences in technological and socioeconomic structures. Based on census data.]

did.unittitle: Analysis of Effects of Urbanization in Five Russian Cities. Joseph Froomkin, 1952

scopecontent.p: [An enumeration of changes in the technological and socioeconomic structure of five Russian cities which have taken place during rapid urbanization. Includes discussion of usefulness of Soviet statistics.]

did.unittitle: Estimating a Nation's Urban Growth. A. J. Jaffe, Carl Hammer and Dorothy Jahn, 1952

scopecontent.p: [A discussion of empirical examples of urban growth and alternative means of estimating such growth.]

did.unittitle: Korean Urbanization: Past Development and Future Potentials. Thomas 0. Wilkinson, 1952

scopecontent.p: [This study is an attempt to provide some pertinent information about the socioeconomic development of Korea and to relate such development to the growth of Korean cities. Based on census data.]

did.unittitle: World Urban Resources Index, Progress Report. Kingsley Davis, Carl Hammer, Hilda Hertz, Lois Pratt, Samuel Pratt and Natalie Rogoff, 1952

scopecontent.p: [A progress report and prospectus for the future of a system for filing quantitative data for the cities of the world with over 100,000 population.]

did.unittitle: Anticipatory Socialization, A Study of Mobility Expectations and Style of Life. Theresa Falaguerra, 1957

scopecontent.p: [This discusses behavioral and attitudinal indicators of expected change in socioeconomic status which appeared in questionnaires administered to car owners in Peoria, Illinois, and San Bernardino, California.]

did.unittitle: The Universe of Cities: Some Preliminary Considerations. Natalie Rogoff, 1953

scopecontent.p: [This report deals with the potential usefulness of the World Urban Resources Index for comparative, systematic analysis and stresses the importance of the context, or universe, of a particular city in such analysis.]

did.unittitle: Relative Merits of Various Formulas for Rates of Growth. Carl Hammer and Natalie Rogoff, 1952

scopecontent.p: [An evaluation of methods of calculation of rates of growth intended for use in large-scale projects.]

did.unittitle: A Functional Interpretation of the Cost-Utility Index. Carl Hammer, 1952

scopecontent.p: [A discussion of operationalizing Otis Dudley Duncan's cost-utility framework.]

did.unittitle: Demographic Indices of the World's Urban Population. Natalie Rogoff, Bonnie Loflin, Thomas Wilkinson and Samuel Baum, 1953

scopecontent.p: [Age structure and sex composition of urban populations. Demographic profiles of some cities. Intercity variation in demographic structure. Based on data on file in World Urban Resources Index.]

did.unittitle: The Mediterranean Region and its Cities. Donald Foley, Judith Blake, Hilda Hertz and Suzette Kettler, 1953

scopecontent.p: [A study of the demographic structure of 94 Mediterranean cities and their economic roles. Based on World Urban Resources Index data.]

scopecontent.p: [This study focussed on the audience for the posters prepared by the Institute for American Democracy and the experiences of the subjects as they saw the material. 400 bus riders in Springfield, Massachusetts, were intensively interviewed using mainly open-ended questionnaires.]

did.unittitle: Impact of Public Service Advertising: A Controlled Study of Anti-Discrimination Car Cards. Leo Srole, Charles Glock and Babette Kass, 1952

scopecontent.p: [Based on 401 interviews with bus riders in Springfield, Massachusetts, this report evaluates audience reaction to a series of posters prepared by the Anti-Defamation League designed to improve attitudes toward minority groups. It discusses such factors as who and how many people saw the posters, and the viewers' comprehension and recall of these posters.]

did.unittitle: William McPhee, Phillip Ennis and Alan Meyer A Progress Report of the 1950 Congressional Voting Study, 1952
did.physdesc: (79 pp.; 14 folders containing Empty folder (McPhee & ...Public Opinion & Congressional Elections), Memos & correspondence, Questionnaires, Articles, Misc. materials, Background material & questionnaires, Article, Codebook, Progress report on study)

Meyer's paper "The Independent Voter" discusses the definition and characteristics of the independent voter, while Ennis's "Contextual Factors in Voting Decisions" examines how differing social and political contexts affect standards of judgement and voting behavior.]

did.physdesc: (298 pp.; 3 folders containing Questionnaire, Empty folder (Report-copy in Vienna), State Department manual- How Important is an Information Program?)

Questionnaire and bibliography included.]

did.unittitle: Paul F. Lazarsfeld and Robert K. Merton Proposal to Establish an Institute for Training in Social Research, 1950

scopecontent.p: [This is concerned with the problems of training in empirical social research. It proposes to establish the institute as a significant step towards a more adequate training program.]

did.unittitle: Training for Social Science Research: A Qualitative Analysis of Factors Affecting the Training of Students for Modern Social Research. Charles R. Wright, 1952

scopecontent.p: [Published as part of doctoral dissertation, "The Effects of Training in Social Research on the Development of Professional Attitudes," Ann Arbor: University Microfilms, 1954.]

did.unittitle: A Formalization of Robert K. Merton's Explanation of "Value Homophily." Paul F. Lazarsfeld, 1953

scopecontent.p: [This paper is an attempt to formalize Merton's theoretical reflections. Merton's analysis of homophily with regard to racial attitudes is presented followed by a formalization of this analysis.]

did.unittitle: The Construction of Indexes: A Common Language and Framework. S. M. Miller, 1953

scopecontent.p: [This paper briefly sketches a model of a research procedure and then explores in detail the general procedure followed at the last stages of an investigation.This paper is an attempt to formalize Merton's theoretical reflections. Merton's analysis of homophily with regard to racial attitudes is presented followed by a formalization of this analysis. REPORT NOT AVAILABLE]

did.unittitle: Historical Materials on Innovations in Higher Education. Bernhard J. Stem, 1953

scopecontent.p: [This is a collection of examples from the history of higher education where innovations in advanced learning were proposed and either adopted or defeated. The purpose was to obtain information on the conditions under which new institutions become necessary, on how ideas develop into concrete plans, and on the forces that aid or hinder these plans. REPORT NOT AVAILABLE]

did.unittitle: The Panel Technique: As a Systematic Introduction to Through-Time Analysis in the Behavioral Sciences. Joseph A. Precker, 1953

scopecontent.p: [This discussion of panel methods for the investigation of attitudes, and other manifestations of social change, is an attempt to organize some of the major studies and techniques into a consistent developing framework. REPORT NOT AVAILABLE]

did.unittitle: Documents for the Seminar on Concepts and Indices in the Social Sciences. Natalie Rogoff, 1953

scopecontent.p: [This is a collection of documents dealing with specification of concepts, formal structure of individual and group characteristics, multi-dimensional classification, attribute space, and derived problems. Case material on specific sociological and economic concepts and specific concepts in social psychology and the measurement of change over time are also discussed. REPORT NOT AVAILABLE]

did.unittitle: Concepts and Indices. Edited by Paul F. Lazarsfeld, 1953

scopecontent.p: [This is a collection of documents from the Dartmouth Seminar on Concepts and Indices, July 11-25, 1953. Part I: Organization and Basic Themes; Part II: Documentation of the Leading Themes; Part II, A: From Imagery to Index-A Schematic Sequence, Part II, B: The Basic Operational Problems; Part III: Additional Case Materials and Reports. REPORT NOT AVAILABLE]

did.unittitle: Analysis of Social Process. Edited by Paul F. Lazarsfeld, 1954

scopecontent.p: [This is a collection of various papers from the Seminar on Social Process Analysis. Reports are: "Methods of Panel Analysis"; "Mutual Effects of Statistical Variables"; "Methodology of Repeated Interview Analysis"; "Notes on Impact Analysis"; "Seminar Discussion of the Relation of Panel and Experiment"; "Notes on Models for a Common Type of Attitude Process"; The Multi-Wave Panel as a Quasi-Experiment"; "Uniformities in the Voting Process"; "Formalization of McPhee's Model."]

did.unittitle: The In-Service Trainee Program of the Bureau of Applied Social Research. Samuel Pratt, 1954

scopecontent.p: [This report evaluates the in-service training program of the Bureau. It describes the general position of the program in the overall organization, the methods of obtaining trainees, the actual processes of training and the problems uncovered.]

did.unittitle: Panel Analysis Workbook. Bernard Levenson, 1958

scopecontent.p: [Panel analysis is a research technique, a method of collecting information about individuals and studying one major class of change. This is a workbook intended to acquaint students with a variety of panel materials and to furnish them with experience in analyzing and experimenting with such data. Many solved problems are included.]

did.unittitle: Case Materials and Case Analysis in American Professional Training. Bernard Barber, 1954

scopecontent.p: [This report on the use of case materials and case analysis in American professional training attempts to define what constitutes such materials, and to consider how they may best be analyzed, by a comparative study of several areas in which there has actually occurred use of some such materials and of some adapted educational techniques. RECORD MAY NOT EXIST]

scopecontent.p: [Twenty-four informal, lengthy conversations about beer drinkers' habits are included and attitudes towards various brands are evaluated.]

scopecontent.p: [Pilot phase of project which studies 27 Girl Scout Councils. Deals with attitudes toward troop sponsorship, cross-pressures involved, and the problem of limited troops (those sponsored by religious organizations).]

scopecontent.p: [The focus of this project is "to produce an accurate and current account of the prevailing climate of opinions and practices of local Girl Scout Councils on the matter of troop sponsorship and on the related problem of limited troops." 894 questionnaires returned.]

did.physdesc: (22 pp.; 5 folders containing A-187 October 1955 issue of Social Problems Journal, Reports, Selected hypothesis on ... in Poland Czechoslovakia & Hungary, Reviews from journals, Interview code)

scopecontent.p: [Report not available]

did.unittitle: John A. Morsell and Ernest Koller Blood Pressure in the World's Medical Literature, 1950

scopecontent.p: [This is the first of a series of reports concerned with the epidemiologic aspects of hypertension. It deals with the collection and mode of classification of a bibliographic file of titles comprising as complete as possible a coverage of world literature on blood pressure since 1920.]

did.unittitle: Studies in Hypertension: A Report on a Program of Planning and Research in the Epidemiology of Essential Hypertension. Charles Glock, 1955

scopecontent.p: [This report presents results of the work done since 1950 by the Columbia staff in developing a detailed design for a long term epidemiologic study of the natural history of essential hypertension. Section I outlines the objectives of the program, presenting the rationale for a longterm study; Section II describes the requirements for such a study; Section III outlines the activities of the staff in satisfying these requirements and Section IV sets forth additional steps recommended before proceeding with the long term project.]

did.unittitle: Lois V. Pratt An Evaluation of Oil Progress Week, 1953

scopecontent.p: [Using Oil Progress Week as a case study, this project examines the extent of attitude change and attitude reinforcement which results from exposure to various media of communication, social position in the community and other social factors. Based on 560 "before and after" interviews, this report describes the events of the Oil Progress Week campaign and the resulting impact on the attitudes of the community towards the oil industry. The report focuses on changes in 10 specific opinions.]

did.unittitle: An Inquiry into Factors Underlying Attitudes Toward the Oil Industry. Hanan C. Selvin, 1953

scopecontent.p: [By applying the technique of latent structure analysis, this report seeks to determine the structure of attitudes toward the oil industry in order to provide a meaningful context in which to study changes in these attitudes brought about by Oil Progress Week. Also discussed are the relationships between opinions and attitudes. The analysis is based on 10 questions asked interviewees before Oil Progress Week.]

did.unittitle: The Effects of Oil Progress Week, 1952: A Supplementary Analysis. Hanan C. Selvin and Arnold G. Simmel, 1954

scopecontent.p: [Based on responses to the same questions as analyzed in B-0461-2, the interviews for this report were conducted after Oil Progress Week instead of before. Changes in the relation of general attitude to specific opinions between the two interviews are studied. Some of the social groupings in which favorable constellations of attitudes occur are also identified.]

did.unittitle: The Effects of Oil Progress Week, 1952: A Summary of a Supplementary Report. Hanan C. Selvin and Arnold G. Simmel, 1954

scopecontent.p: [This report summarizes in a briefer and less technical manner B-0461-3.]
